awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is to develop silicon(Si)-based rechargeable batteries that can simultaneously provide ultrafast charging capability, high specific energy and long-lasting cycle life. Such rechargeable batteries will allow cell phones to be charged to their full capacity within 20 min (rather than 2 hours offered by the current battery technology available in the market) while extending the usage time to 3 days (rather than 2 days of current technology) before recharge is needed. These ultrafast charging and high energy batteries can also find a market for other consumer products, such as cameras, laptops, drones, power tools, electric forklifts in warehouses, and military devices, to improve work productivity and life quality for consumers. Furthermore, Si-based high energy batteries can be utilized to reduce the cost and weight of electric vehicle battery packs by 60%. These advancements will pave the way for broad market penetration of electric vehicles and support a more environmentally sustainable mode of transportation. 

This I-Corps project employs a novel, simple and low-cost manufacturing method that can synthesize a new type of Si-based anode powder which exhibits unusual properties with ultrafast charging capability, high specific capacity and long-lasting cycle life. This new Si-based anode is termed as Si@void@C because it contains three distinct features simultaneously: (i) nanostructured Si building blocks, (ii) a conductive carbon shell outside the nanostructured Si core, and (iii) engineered void space inside the Si core. Together these three features offer the much-needed properties for Li-ion batteries: ultrafast charging capability, high specific energy and long-lasting cycle life. Based on these unique properties, the Si-based rechargeable batteries are designed in two general categories, one being "ultrafast charging batteries" that can shorten the charging time to 20 min while still allowing cell phones to be used for 3 days before re-charge and the other being "high energy batteries" which require 2 hours charging time, but allow users to recharge batteries every 6 days. Furthermore, "high energy batteries" can enable a reduction in the cost of the battery packs by 60% for electric vehicles, removing a critical barrier to consumer acceptance.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
The objectives of this I-Corps entrepreneurial education are to probe the rechargeable battery market and identify potential "customers and their needs” for our high energy density Si-based rechargeable batteries. Following our NSF I-Corps entrepreneurial education in spring 2019, we have interviewed 180+ potential customers and identify their specific needs for rechargeable batteries. We traveled to visit many companies nationwide and attend many trade shows in the U.S. The battery users we interviewed can be grouped into 5 major categories: (a) electric vehicle (EV) manufacturers, (b) electric aircraft (EA) manufacturers for urban air mobility (UAM) and on-demand mobility (ODM) transport, (c) commercial drone users and manufacturers, (d) outdoor and indoor robot manufacturers, and (e) consumer electronic users. The key findings from these interviews are summarized below.

 

  1. High performance rechargeable batteries are the enabling technology and will play a critical role for the success of many industry sectors and emerging industries.
  2. Different industry sectors have different requirements for rechargeable batteries.
  3. The two top challenges faced by electric vehicle (EV) manufacturers are (i) cost of battery packs and (ii) driving distance per charge in addition to safety.
  4. The two top battery challenges for eVTOL aircraft manufacturers are (i) flying distance per charge and (ii) fast charge/discharge with safety. The cost is not their priority as the profit margin for aerospace industry is much higher than automobile industry.
  5. The number one requirement for drone batteries is fly time per charge, i.e., high specific energy of the battery. We also learn that there are many emerging applications for commercial drones, including package delivery, defect inspection for production of tall and large structures and machines inside manufacturing facilities, surveying land, taking detailed readings of water levels or pesticide levels on swaths of agricultural land, helping the first responders in saving lives, enabling fire management and resource management during a natural disaster, relaying radio and wireless internet hotspots to restore service after a natural disaster, and enhancing military capabilities in a wide range of activities.
  6. In the area of robots, they can be grouped into two general categories with one for in-door applications and the other for out-door applications. For in-door applications such as robots to transfer goods on pallets around the warehouse, “opportunity” charge technology is used, and there is no need for high energy density batteries. However, for the out-door applications such as gardening and farming by robots, high energy density batteries are desired.
  7. There is no clear number one priority for the technology of rechargeable batteries in consumer electronic industry as a whole. Improvements in charge speed, energy density and cost reduction are desired, but not a must for this industry to thrive further. Further, the technical requirements for rechargeable batteries in consumer electronic industry are lower than those in electric vehicle, electric aircraft and commercial drone industries.

 

This I-Corps project has also offered opportunities for training and professional development for several students. In addition to the three members of the project team (i.e., the Entrepreneurial lead (EL), the I-Corps Team Mentor (IM), and the Technical Lead and Principal Investigator (TL and PI)), we also supported 3 additional graduate students to participate in the NSF Midwest I-Corps program by attending webinars on July 11 and July 25, 2019 and then attending the Center for Automotive Research (CAR) Management Briefing Seminar in Traverse City, MI from August 5th to 8th. All three students have learned how to do customer discovery by asking unbiased questions and identifying the key pain points of potential customers. The I-Corps entrepreneurial education has also stimulated the interest of the students in entrepreneurship.


Last Modified: 01/26/2022
Modified by: Leon L Shaw
por.por_txt_cntn:
The objectives of this I-Corps entrepreneurial education are to probe the rechargeable battery market and identify potential "customers and their needs" for our high energy density Si-based rechargeable batteries. Following our NSF I-Corps entrepreneurial education in spring 2019, we have interviewed 180+ potential customers and identify their specific needs for rechargeable batteries. We traveled to visit many companies nationwide and attend many trade shows in the U.S. The battery users we interviewed can be grouped into 5 major categories: (a) electric vehicle (EV) manufacturers, (b) electric aircraft (EA) manufacturers for urban air mobility (UAM) and on-demand mobility (ODM) transport, (c) commercial drone users and manufacturers, (d) outdoor and indoor robot manufacturers, and (e) consumer electronic users. The key findings from these interviews are summarized below.
 

High performance rechargeable batteries are the enabling technology and will play a critical role for the success of many industry sectors and emerging industries.
Different industry sectors have different requirements for rechargeable batteries.
The two top challenges faced by electric vehicle (EV) manufacturers are (i) cost of battery packs and (ii) driving distance per charge in addition to safety.
The two top battery challenges for eVTOL aircraft manufacturers are (i) flying distance per charge and (ii) fast charge/discharge with safety. The cost is not their priority as the profit margin for aerospace industry is much higher than automobile industry.
The number one requirement for drone batteries is fly time per charge, i.e., high specific energy of the battery. We also learn that there are many emerging applications for commercial drones, including package delivery, defect inspection for production of tall and large structures and machines inside manufacturing facilities, surveying land, taking detailed readings of water levels or pesticide levels on swaths of agricultural land, helping the first responders in saving lives, enabling fire management and resource management during a natural disaster, relaying radio and wireless internet hotspots to restore service after a natural disaster, and enhancing military capabilities in a wide range of activities. 
In the area of robots, they can be grouped into two general categories with one for in-door applications and the other for out-door applications. For in-door applications such as robots to transfer goods on pallets around the warehouse, "opportunity" charge technology is used, and there is no need for high energy density batteries. However, for the out-door applications such as gardening and farming by robots, high energy density batteries are desired.
There is no clear number one priority for the technology of rechargeable batteries in consumer electronic industry as a whole. Improvements in charge speed, energy density and cost reduction are desired, but not a must for this industry to thrive further. Further, the technical requirements for rechargeable batteries in consumer electronic industry are lower than those in electric vehicle, electric aircraft and commercial drone industries. 

 
This I-Corps project has also offered opportunities for training and professional development for several students. In addition to the three members of the project team (i.e., the Entrepreneurial lead (EL), the I-Corps Team Mentor (IM), and the Technical Lead and Principal Investigator (TL and PI)), we also supported 3 additional graduate students to participate in the NSF Midwest I-Corps program by attending webinars on July 11 and July 25, 2019 and then attending the Center for Automotive Research (CAR) Management Briefing Seminar in Traverse City, MI from August 5th to 8th. All three students have learned how to do customer discovery by asking unbiased questions and identifying the key pain points of potential customers. The I-Corps entrepreneurial education has also stimulated the interest of the students in entrepreneurship.
